reasoning:
Centrality: The critique targets one illustrative sub-argument (digital-being rights as a major moral-axis increasing fragility). This is part of the paper’s broader case that there are many ways to lose value, but it is not load-bearing for the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion; removing/weakening this example would modestly weaken the case, not collapse it.

Strength: It raises a substantive, under-discussed complication: adversarially-created pseudo-patients could make the governance problem more like security/attack-surface management than a symmetric “rights/no-rights” moral uncertainty. That does undercut the paper’s presentation if the paper implies the digital-being issue is just another independent moral dimension. However, it doesn’t actually show the paper’s conclusion is wrong, and it’s also largely compatible with (even supportive of) the paper’s broader claim that moral failure modes are numerous and non-obvious; it mostly argues the paper has mischaracterized the structure (one bottleneck vs many independent factors).

Correctness: The adversarial dynamic is plausible and internally coherent, and it’s true the essay doesn’t obviously integrate it explicitly. But the critique overreaches in claiming this makes the digital-being discussion “not evidence of many independent moral dimensions” (it could be both a security bottleneck and still one dimension among many), and it doesn’t justify that the bottleneck would dominate overall feasibility.

Clarity: The objection is specific (manufacture of moral patients; verification vs exclusion dilemma) and the demanded revision is clear (incorporate adversarial economics/security of moral status).

Dead weight: Minimal; almost all sentences serve the objection.

Single issue: Focused on one core point (adversarial manipulation of moral status in digital-being rights/governance).

Overall: A thoughtful, relevant refinement/pressure on one example and on the “independent dimensions” framing, but it only modestly threatens the overall position and is not fully argued to the point of decisive refutation.
title: Adversarial creation of moral patients creates a security bottleneck the paper ignores
